name: NPR
text:
JUST IN: President Trump is seriously considering running for a second term as president in 2024, two campaign sources and a third source with close ties to Trump's circle tell NPR.
https://t.co/H0fgs1UXY6

name: NPR
text:
RT @SachaPfeiffer: Love to read? Want new book ideas?

Meet the 2020 Book Concierge by @NPR & @nprbooks. It's beautiful and useful. And it contains nearly 2,500 titles, including about 380 from this year.

My pick is "Before the Ever After" by ultra-talented @JackieWoodson: https://t.co/5LoIKWTRle

name: NPR
text:
Virginia's Campbell County is calling on county agencies not to enforce Gov. Ralph Northam's crowd-size limits and other COVID-19 restrictions, saying they violate individual rights.
https://t.co/FVKF4AsHxj

name: NPR
text:
RT @davidfolkenflik: Under Trump pick Michael Pack, USAGM probably committed wrongdoing toward Voice of America and other networks it funds, federal watchdog finds 

https://t.co/PLjlT8pWhl

name: NPR
text: Open enrollment in ACA plans is ongoing until Dec. 15 in most states. Here are tips if you're shopping for health insurance — especially if you have lingering effects of COVID-19 or other health issues: https://t.co/bPwpD4xdt9

name: NPR
text:
After weeks of pushing false claims about voter fraud, President Trump's allies in Georgia went even further at a rally on Wednesday — discouraging residents from voting in the Jan. 5 Senate runoff election. 
https://t.co/85v6MijXUa

name: NPR
text: Jazz Standard is the first major jazz club in New York City to close permanently due to the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/lZnj81xMtD

name: NPR
text:
A bipartisan group of lawmakers, including key GOP leaders, are balking at Trump's threat to veto the annual defense bill, which sets policy for the Pentagon and military service members, and are moving ahead as planned.
https://t.co/2U6FicfEYc

name: NPR
text:
RT @hansilowang: NEW: Leaked documents obtained by House @OversightDems confirm President Trump’s attempt to alter a key #2020Census count may be undermined by inconvenient timing regardless of how #SCOTUS rules, but data release dates appear to be edging closer to Jan. 20
https://t.co/ZiJqEQM9ei

name: NPR
text:
The Kremlin is betting on the Russian-made vaccine Sputnik V — still in phase 3 clinical trials — to help stop the spread of COVID-19, saying mass vaccinations will be free of charge and carried out voluntarily. 
https://t.co/10a8XnYqPr

name: NPR
text:
When a company’s coronavirus tests came under scrutiny, two board members each cashed in nearly $1 million worth of company stock. But the sales were not disclosed until days after the legal deadline.  
https://t.co/KbyuJEWk1S

name: NPR
text:
A band of at least 20 armed gangsters staged a coordinated attack on a bank in the remote Brazilian city of Cametá — just one day after a bank was robbed in Criciúma, 2,000 miles away.
https://t.co/PpwwM526B6

name: NPR
text:
James Ramos, the first member of a California Native American tribe to serve in the state legislature, authored 3 new laws bolstering the rights of Native Americans in the state that will take effect Jan. 1.
https://t.co/o9NwS4mC40

name: NPR
text:
Dr. Robert Atmar, a CDC adviser, says some front-line workers are hesitant to receive a COVID-19 vaccine first — but says he's speaking with staff to "reassure that there weren't any steps that were skipped."
https://t.co/vSeCxBvUST

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has sentenced a former Arizona public official to 6 years in prison for his role in an international smuggling scheme trafficking pregnant women from the Marshall Islands to the U.S. to profit from their newborn babies.
https://t.co/pLEZOSeI3U

name: NPR
text:
Two young girls in Kentucky are making and selling yard signs that say "Be Kind" — and donating the proceeds to local charities.

"We felt that every place could use more kindness because there's never too much kindness," said Raegan, 12.
https://t.co/xUbZ6eppNI

name: NPR
text:
A freelance writer says her Substack newsletter gives her the freedom to write something that "you can't really pitch to a site that's looking to get a lot of clicks" through a social media algorithm.
https://t.co/oNfII4eHmA

name: NPR
text:
A coronavirus testing company claimed its tests had demonstrated 100% accuracy in independent evaluations. A medical expert called those claims “laughable" and impossible to achieve in the real world.
https://t.co/huccliKNeI

name: NPR
text:
Former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton say they're willing to publicly take a coronavirus vaccine once it's available in the U.S. to encourage Americans who are hesitant.
https://t.co/RaIFJ16WF9

name: NPR
text:
The National Labor Relations Board alleges Google illegally fired two employees involved in labor organizing last year.

It also says the tech giant surveilled employees who viewed a union organizing presentation.
https://t.co/kx09cTLEn1

name: NPR
text:
Bread shortages are now widespread in Syria.

One man who spoke with NPR says he leaves his home at dawn to stand in line for up to 6 hours to get two bags of bread.

After that, he often waits at the gas station for another 6 hours to buy fuel for work.
https://t.co/j1kLxtJwGJ

name: NPR
text:
RT @LouderThanARiot: Women are often written off in rap & made invisible in the prison system. There's one Philly rapper pushing back against that.
 
In this ep, our editor @ChiquitaPaschal shows how her sister @IsisThaSaviour uses hip-hop to transform trauma into freedom.
 
https://t.co/rzO0ttH5Td https://t.co/twjHHOidlM

name: NPR
text:
BREAKING: In a last-minute push, the Trump administration has announced it will auction off drilling rights in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in just over a month.

If leases are finalized before Biden takes office, they could be difficult to revoke.
https://t.co/j9X8QsvNAk

name: NPR
text:
Hip-Hop loves the story of an underdog. But the culture tends to not see women as heroes.

@louderthanariot follows the hero's journey of Philly rapper Isis Tha Saviour and looks at how the art of hip-hop can help transform trauma into freedom. https://t.co/x8TH4rglkO https://t.co/WD48a0kmpa

name: NPR
text:
Gitanjali Rao, 15, has been named Time's Kid of the Year for 2020 for her work inventing a mobile device to test for lead in drinking water.

"I really want to put out that message: If I can do it, you can do it — and anyone can do it," she says.
https://t.co/rZ2EDgU4EC

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: NEW: The Supreme Court vacated a decision that upheld restrictions on houses of worship imposed by California during the COVID-19 pandemic. 

The court told a lower court to reconsider its decision in light of last week’s 5-4 decision blocking similar restrictions in New York.NEW: The Supreme Court vacated a decision that upheld restrictions on houses of worship imposed by California durin… https://t.co/i620Ewf44p

name: NPR
text:
How has the iconic family-owned Portland bookstore @Powells weathered 2020? 

@HowIBuiltThis host @GuyRaz is interviewing Emily Powell – the bookstore's President and Owner.

What should they cover? Tweet questions with #HIBTLive.

Supported by @hubspot. https://t.co/ULDd11YRnP

name: NPR
text:
RT @elizblair: For years, serious writers about Billie Holiday have heard the name Linda Kuehl. Before she died in 1978, Kuehl interviewed some 150 people who knew Billie best. Finally we can hear those interviews. Also includes restored concert footage. #Billie @npr 
https://t.co/Sq8SsEu1pX

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Biden has tapped former Obama aide Brian Deese to be his top economic adviser at the White House.

The pick has raised the ire of some progressive groups because of Deese's work for investment giant BlackRock.
https://t.co/o2JUmDVsZL

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration is rushing ahead to sell drilling rights in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge next month before Biden takes office.

If leases are finalized before Biden's inauguration, they could be tough to revoke.
https://t.co/qN412ON5cj

name: NPR
text:
The National Labor Relations Board alleges Google violated federal law when it fired two employees involved in labor organizing last year.
https://t.co/XJmqzxKNcN

name: NPR
text:
Many Republican voters have been swayed by President Trump's baseless claims about voter fraud and the results of the election.

Now, party leaders are worrying that message could deter voters — particularly in next month's Georgia Senate runoffs.
https://t.co/L09ADrQVq4

name: NPR
text:
This Seattle hospital faced the United States' initial swell of coronavirus cases earlier this year.

Now, health care workers there are offering advice to people facing the latest surge in COVID-19 patients.
https://t.co/mkIkMblNR8

name: NPR
text:
More Americans stayed home for Thanksgiving this year compared with 2019 — but by relatively small margins, according to an analysis of anonymized smartphone data.

It found the majority of Americans with smartphones still traveled, despite CDC warnings.
https://t.co/GiD82Ms5wi

name: NPR
text:
There's another monolith.
https://t.co/ZBsGkbCChM
